hints_html: A vertical tangent line means that the derivative is undefined at the point. As for the sketch, use the previous parts of this question to help with your drawing.
hints_latex:
A vertical tangent line means that the derivative is undefined at the
point. As for the sketch, use the previous parts of this question to
help with your drawing.
hints_raw: A vertical tangent line means that the derivative is undefined at the point. As for the sketch, use the previous parts of this question to help with your drawing.
question: 5 (e)
sols_html:
From parts (a) and (d), we know that the critical values for the first and second derivative of \(f(x)\) are \(x = -1, x = 0\), and \(x = 4\). We first calculate the corresponding y-values for the x-values named above ...

  • \(\displaystyle x = -1\), \(\displaystyle y = f(-1) = 6(-1)^{1/5} + (-1)^{6/5} = -6 + 1 = -5\)

  • \(\displaystyle x = 0\), \(\displaystyle y = f(0) = 6(0)^{1/5} + (0)^{6/5} = 0\)

  • \(\displaystyle x = 4\), \(\displaystyle y = f(4) = 6(4)^{1/5} + (4)^{6/5} \approx 13.2\)

...and then plot these points on the graph.

From part (b), we know the function is decreasing until the point \((-1, -5)\) and then increasing. Thus the function has a minimum at that point. Because the derivative is undefined at \((0,0)\), it has a vertical tangent line there.

Schematically, the tangent lines and increase/decrease of the function looks like this.

However, we know the function isn’t made up of straight lines - it’s more curvy than that. From part (d) we know that the function has an inflection point at \(x = 0\) and \(x = 4\). Furthermore we know that the function is concave up for \(x < 0\) and \(x > 4\) and is concave down for \(0 < x < 4\). This tells us what our curves should look like.

If we superimpose the curve on top of the straight lines it looks something like this:

So the final graph should look like this:
sols_latex:
From parts (a) and (d), we know that the critical values for the first
and second derivative of $f(x)$ are $x = -1, x = 0$, and $x = 4$. We
first calculate the corresponding y-values for the x-values named above
...

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\displaystyle x = -1$,
  $\displaystyle y = f(-1) = 6(-1)^{1/5} + (-1)^{6/5} = -6 + 1 = -5$
\item
  $\displaystyle x = 0$,
  $\displaystyle y = f(0) = 6(0)^{1/5} + (0)^{6/5} = 0$
\item
  $\displaystyle x = 4$,
  $\displaystyle y = f(4) = 6(4)^{1/5} + (4)^{6/5} \approx 13.2$
\end{itemize}

...and then plot these points on the graph.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2011/Math_ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December_2011Question_05_(e)Solution_1a.jpg}

From part (b), we know the function is decreasing until the point
$(-1, -5)$ and then increasing. Thus the function has a minimum at that
point. Because the derivative is undefined at $(0,0)$, it has a vertical
tangent line there.

Schematically, the tangent lines and increase/decrease of the function
looks like this.

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2011/Math_ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December_2011Question_05_(e)Solution_1b.jpg}

However, we know the function isn't made up of straight lines - it's
more curvy than that. From part (d) we know that the function has an
inflection point at $x = 0$ and $x = 4$. Furthermore we know that the
function is concave up for $x < 0$ and $x > 4$ and is concave down for
$0 < x < 4$. This tells us what our curves should look like.

If we superimpose the curve on top of the straight lines it looks
something like this:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2011/Math_ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December_2011Question_05_(e)Solution_1c.jpg}

So the final graph should look like this:

\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH100/December_2011/Math_ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December_2011Question_05_(e)Solution_1d-002.jpg}
sols_raw:
From parts (a) and (d), we know that the critical values for the first and second derivative of <math>f(x)</math> are <math>x = -1, x = 0</math>, and <math>x = 4</math>.  We first calculate the corresponding y-values for the x-values named above ... 

* <math> \displaystyle x = -1</math>, <math>  \displaystyle y = f(-1) = 6(-1)^{1/5} + (-1)^{6/5} = -6 + 1 = -5 </math>
* <math>  \displaystyle  x = 0</math>, <math>  \displaystyle y = f(0) = 6(0)^{1/5} + (0)^{6/5} = 0 </math>
* <math> \displaystyle  x = 4</math>, <math>  \displaystyle  y = f(4) = 6(4)^{1/5} + (4)^{6/5} \approx 13.2</math>

...and then plot these points on the graph.  

[[File:Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1a.jpg]]

From part (b), we know the function is decreasing until the point <math>(-1, -5)</math> and then increasing.  Thus the function has a minimum at that point.  Because the derivative is undefined at <math>(0,0)</math>, it has a vertical tangent line there.  

Schematically, the tangent lines and increase/decrease of the function  looks like this.  

[[File:Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1b.jpg]]

However, we know the function isn't made up of straight lines - it's more curvy than that.  From part (d) we know that the function has an inflection point at <math>x = 0</math> and <math>x = 4</math>.  Furthermore we know that the function is concave up for <math>x < 0</math> and <math>x > 4</math> and is concave down for <math>0 < x < 4</math>.  This tells us what our curves should look like.  

If we superimpose the curve on top of the straight lines it looks something like this: 

[[File:Math ExamResourcesCoursesMATH100December 2011Question 05 (e)Solution 1c.jpg]]

So the final graph should look like this:

statement_html:
Full-Solution Problems. In questions 2-8, justify your answers and show all your work. Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.

Let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}\end{aligned}\]

Sketch the graph of \(y=f(x)\) and indicate the inflection points on your graph. Please also indicate the point(s) on your graph at which the graph of \(y=f(x)\) has a vertical tangent line.
statement_raw:
'''''Full-Solution Problems.''' In questions 2-8, justify your answers and '''show all your work.''' Simplification of answers is not required unless explicitly stated.''

Let
:<math>\displaystyle
y=f(x)=6x^{1/5}+x^{6/5}
</math>

Sketch the graph of <math>y=f(x)</math> and indicate the inflection points on your graph. Please also indicate the point(s) on your graph at which the graph of <math>y=f(x)</math> has a vertical tangent line.
